column1: Gladstone  is a city in the Gladstone Region
column3: Australia. It is approximately 550 km (340 mi) by road north-west of the state capital
column4: Brisbane
column5: and 100 km (62 mi) south-east of Rockhampton. Situated between the Calliope and Boyne Rivers
column6: Gladstone is home to Queensland's largest multi-commodity shipping port.

column1: Gladstone
column2: together with Boyne Island and Tannum Sands
column3: had an estimated urban population of 45
column4: 130 at June 2018. This urban area covers 246.1 km2 (95.0 sq mi).Gladstone is the largest town within the Gladstone Region and the headquarters of Gladstone Regional Council is located in Gladstone. The Gladstone Region was formed in 2008 through the amalgamation of three former local government areas.

column1: == History ==
Before European settlement
column2: the Gladstone region was home of the Gooreng Gooreng
column4: Meerooni and Baiali (or Byellee) Aboriginal tribes.

column1: In May 1770
column3: under the command of James Cook
column4: sailed by the entrance to Gladstone Harbour under the cover of darkness. Matthew Flinders
column6: became the first recorded European to sight the harbour in August 1802. He named the harbour Port Curtis
column8: a man who was of assistance to Flinders a year earlier at the Cape of Good Hope. John Oxley conducted further exploration of the harbour and surrounding countryside in November 1823. Oxley was dismissive of the region
column9: noting the harbour was difficult to enter
column11: and the timber useless for construction purposes.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: in 1847 the British attempted to establish the new colony of North Australia at Port Curtis. Colonel George Barney was chosen to lead this experiment in colonisation and his expedition was eventful. On 25 January 1847
column4: carrying 87 soldiers and convicts
column5: arrived off the southern entrance of Port Curtis and promptly ran aground on shoals off the southern tip of Facing Island. The settlers spent seven weeks on the island before being rescued by the supply ship Thomas Lowry and delivered the intended site of settlement
column6: the region now known as Barney Point. On 30 January at a proclamation ceremony
column7: Barney was sworn in as Lieutenant Governor of the colony of North Australia. The convict settlement lasted barely two months and cost the Imperial government £15
column8: 000. A change of government in Britain ordered the withdrawal of Barney and the settlers. However

column2: Francis MacCabe was surveying the site of a new town on the shores of Port Curtis under the protection of several detachments of Native Police. Maurice O'Connell was appointed government resident the following year
column3: resulting in an influx of free settlers as land became available throughout the region.

column1: Gladstone State School opened on 1 April 1861 and is one of the oldest state primary schools in Queensland. On 14 November 1968 its name was changed to be Gladstone Central State School.In 1863
column2: the town became a Municipality with Richard Hetherington elected Gladstone's first mayor. The fledgling town was named after the British Prime Minister William Ewart Gladstone and has a 19th-century marble statue on display in its town museum.Development of Gladstone was slow until 1893 when a meatworks was established at Parsons Point.

column1: Parson's Point Provisional School opened on 1 August 1898
column2: becoming Parson's Point State School on 1 February 1913. The school was relocated and renamed Gladstone South State School in 1945.On 2 March 1949
column4: resulting in extensive damage to the town.Gladstone State High School opened on 2 February 1953.In 1963
column5: Queensland Alumina Limited established its alumina refinery on the site of the old meatworks. Gladstone's port facilities were expanded and the city launched into an era of industrial development and economic prosperity.

column1: Gladstone West State School opened on 24 January 1966.Rosella Park State School was opened on 17 May 1971.Clinton State School opened on 29 January 1974.Toolooa State High School opened on 27 January 1981.Kin Kora State School opened on 9 October 1981.In 1985 the Gladstone Christian Community School opened as a primary school operated by the Gladstone Baptist Church. In 1998
column2: it changed its name to Trinity College. From 2013 it offered classes from Prep to Year 12.St Stephens Lutheran College opened in 1998
column3: but closed at the end of 2016. The school had lost 20% of its enrolment due to families moving away to find work
column4: leaving only 216 students in classes ranging from Prep to Year 12 making it no longer viable to operate the school.Gladstone Cinemas
column5: a locally owned and operated independent cinema
column6: was a welcome addition to the Gladstone Region in March 2001.

column1: The Gladstone Library building opened in 2003.

== Population ==
According to the 2016 census of population
column3: 418 people in the Gladstone urban centre.

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 4.6% of the population.
76.0% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were New Zealand 3.7%
column4: India 1.3% and South Africa 1.0%.

column1: 84.4% of people only spoke English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Tagalog 1.1%
column4: Mandarin 0.4% and Hindi 0.4%.

column1: The most common responses for religion were No Religion 29.9%
== Geography ==
Gladstone and Rockhampton are the two major cities in the Central Queensland region. In the sister city program
column2: Gladstone is twinned with the Japanese port of Saiki.

column1: === Suburbs ===
* – the historic center of the city and major business district
=== Climate ===

Gladstone experiences a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification cfa) and is one of the northernmost places in Australia to have this classification. Extreme temperatures in Gladstone have ranged from 4.4 to 42.0 °C (39.9 to 107.6 °F). These temperatures were recorded by the Bureau of Meteorology.
The temperature recording for the below table were performed at the following location—23.8553°S 151.2628°E 75m AMSL
== Industry ==

Gladstone's primary industries are mining-related. The Port of Gladstone is the fifth-largest multi-commodity port in Australia and the world's fourth-largest coal-exporting terminal. The port consists of a number of wharves and terminal facilities. Boyne Wharf is used by the Boyne Island aluminium smelter and was opened in August 1982. The western harbour basin has been expanded
column2: primarily to allow increased exports of liquified natural gas (LNG). Furthermore
column4: a plant was constructed on Curtis Island to produce and export LNG
column5: a construction project that contributed heavily to city's population and housing boom. Major exports include coal
column9: sodium cyanide and ammonium nitrate. Each year 50 million tonnes of coal passes through the port
column10: making up 70% of the total exports.Gladstone harbor is within the World Heritage Area of the Great Barrier Reef and has historically supported a thriving seafood industry. In August 2011
column11: a Fisheries Queensland spokesman said they received reports of fish with milky eyes. A spokesman from the Gladstone Fish Markets claimed that diseased fish were still being caught in large numbers in November 2011. Losses to the local seafood industry have been estimated at A$36 million a year.Gladstone is also a tourism destination
column12: with cruise ships regularly docking at the port.

column1: == Education ==
Gladstone has a range of primary schools and secondary schools.
Gladstone Central State School is a government primary (P-6) school for boys and girls at 74 Auckland Street. In 2017
column2: the school had an enrolment of 342 students with 24 teachers (22 full-time equivalent) and 16 non-teaching staff (12 full-time equivalent).Gladstone West State School is a government primary (P-6) school for boys and girls at Boles Street
column3: West Gladstone. In 2017 the school had an enrolment of 647 students with 46 teachers (43 full-time equivalent) and 31 non-teaching staff (20 full-time equivalent).Gladstone South State School is a government primary (P-6) school for boys and girls at 153 Toolooa Street
column4: South Gladstone. In 2017 the school had an enrolment of 330 students with 22 teacher (20 full-time equivalent) and 24 non-teaching staff (16 full-time equivalent).Clinton State School ia a government primary (P-6) school for boys and girls at Harvey Street
column5: Clinton. In 2017 the school had an enrolment of 912 students with 64 teachers (59 full-time equivalent) and 46 non-teaching staff (28 full-time equivalent).Kin Kora State School is a government primary (P-6) school for boys and girls at 43 Hibiscus Avenue
column6: Kin Kora. In 2017 the school had an enrolment of 801 students with 57 teachers (51 full-time equivalent) and 27 non-teaching staff (19 full-time equivalent).Rosella Park School is a government school for boys and girls aged from five to eighteen years who have moderate to severe intellectual impairments at 20 Park Street (corner of Rosella Street)
column7: West Gladstone. In 2017 the school had an enrolment of 75 students with 20 teachers (19 full-time equivalent) and 30 non-teaching staff (19 full-time equivalent). Due to the specialised nature of the school
column8: its students are drawn from all over Gladstone and beyond into the wider Gladstone Region.Gladstone State High School is a government secondary (7–12) school for boys and girls at 30 Dawson Road
column9: West Gladstone. In 2017 the school had an enrolment of 1509 students with 123 teachers (115 full-time equivalent) and 61 non-teaching staff (45 full-time equivalent).Toolooa State High School is a government secondary (7–12) school for boys and girls at 2 Phillip Street
column10: South Gladstone. In 2018 the school had an enrolment of 1
column11: 004 students with 85 teachers (79 full-time equivalent) and 51 non-teaching staff (33 full-time equivalent).It has two main private schools: St Johns and Trinity College.

column1: It also has two university campuses
column2: Central Queensland University. Gladstone was also formerly home to CQIT (TAFE) Gladstone Campus
column3: before it combined with Central Queensland University
column4: becoming the Gladstone City Campus.

column1: == Community facilities ==
The Gladstone Regional Council operates Gladstone Library at 39 Goondoon Street
column2: Gladstone.The Gladstone branch of the Queensland Country Women's Association meets at the QCWA Hall at 88 Oaka Lane

column1: == Recreation ==
Gladstone has direct access to Heron Island
column3: Curtis Island and other islands from the marina and local airstrips.

column1: === Boyne Island and Tannum Sands ===
Boyne Island and Tannum Sands have grown in popularity because of their beautiful beaches and relaxed lifestyle. The Millennium Esplanade is a big attraction where there are lots of shelters
column3: and long stretches of beach. Boyne Island and Tannum Sands are not part of the Gladstone township but are part of the Gladstone region and formerly part of the Calliope Shire.

column1: === Lake Awoonga ===
A little further afield (25 km south of Gladstone) is Lake Awoonga. The recreation area has free barbecues
column4: as well as a caravan park. The lake has been stocked with several fish species since 1996
column5: and over 2 million barramundi have been released. In addition to the fishing
column6: Lake Awoonga has many natural attractions
column8: with more than 225 species of birds (or over 27% of Australia's bird species) found in the region. Lake Awoonga is also the primary source of Gladstone's water supply. Awoonga dam is not part of the Gladstone township but is part of the Gladstone region and formerly part of the Calliope Shire.

column1: == Politics ==
Gladstone is located within the federal electoral division of Flynn
column2: a marginal seat currently held by the Liberal National Party of Queensland's Ken O'Dowd in Federal elections
column3: and the state electoral district of Gladstone
column4: held by the ALP's Glenn Butcher.

column1: == Transport ==
The Dawson Highway originates in Gladstone
column2: and it runs westwards for approximately 400 km (250 mi) to Springsure.

column1: === Rail ===
Gladstone is a major stop on the North Coast railway line
column2: with long-distance passenger trains operated by QR Traveltrain stopping in the area. Gladstone is also the transshipping point for export coal from the Moura and Blackwater coal basins and is one of the largestest coal export ports in The Southern Hemisphere. Currently
column3: coal trains of up to 1.7 km in length and 10
column4: 600 tonnes' gross weight are run by rail operators Aurizon and Pacific National to unload at coal terminals at Barney Point
column6: and Yarwun. Domestic coal is also railed to the Gladstone Power Station and the Queensland Alumina Limited refinery. An extensive rail facility is located at Callemondah to support these operations.

column1: Gladstone was also a major terminus for rail freight and bulk fuel
column2: with extensive marshaling yards at Gladstone
column4: and Auckland Point. As is the case in much of Queensland this traffic
column6: has now ceased with goods carried by road.

column1: Gladstone Airport is located in the western suburbs of Gladstone about 6 km (3.7 mi) (8-minute drive) from the centre of the city.
The main provider of scheduled passenger air services has been QantasLink
column2: using mostly Bombardier Q400 aircraft though Flight West Airlines and Ansett also previously offered service. Strategic Airlines briefly offered services in 2011 and Virgin Australia commenced flights in October 2011 and now offers up to 6 return flights a day to Brisbane mostly on ATR 72 aircraft with Embraer 190 and Boeing 737 also a regular appearance in the schedule. New players JetGo started flying direct services from Sydney in December 2014. The service was offered twice daily
column3: in 36-seat Embraer 135LR jets but ceased in February 2015.

column1: In May 2009
column2: a $65 million upgrade to the airport and nearby area was undertaken

column1: The Port of Gladstone is Queensland's largest multi-commodity port and the fifth-largest multi-commodity port in Australia. It is the world's fourth-largest coal-exporting terminal.
== Media ==
=== Newspapers ===
Gladstone's daily newspaper is The Observer
column2: which is owned by APN News & Media and is issued each morning from Monday to Saturday.

column1: Gladstone also has a free weekly independent community newspaper called Gladstone News.
=== Radio ===
4CC is Gladstone's local AM commercial radio station
column2: owned by Grant Broadcasters. 4CC has one full-time announcer based in Gladstone to present the station's local breakfast show. The station broadcasts to Central Queensland on four separate frequencies via three AM transmitters in Gladstone
column4: and a FM translator in Agnes Water on the Discovery Coast.

column1: Hit Central Queensland is Gladstone's local FM commercial radio station
column2: owned by Southern Cross Austereo. Hot FM has two full-time announcers based in Gladstone to present the station's flagship weekday breakfast program
column3: which is also broadcast to Rockhampton and Emerald.

column1: Gladstone also receives radio stations that carry local programming from Rockhampton including commercial radio stations Triple M Central Queensland and 4RO. Triple M broadcasts on a separate FM frequency in Gladstone.
ABC Capricornia also broadcasts into Gladstone from Rockhampton
column2: using a separate FM frequency. Until November 2014
column3: ABC Capricornia maintained a local news bureau in Gladstone where a local journalist was based to cover the Gladstone region. Some local news bulletins on ABC Capricornia were also broadcast live from Gladstone. However
column4: in what was a controversial decision
column5: the ABC's Gladstone office was permanently closed in late 2014 as a cost-cutting measure following the Federal Government's decision to withdraw $254 million in funding to the ABC.91.9 Fresh FM is Gladstone's local community radio radio station
column6: which has a Christian radio format.

column1: === Television ===
WIN Television
column4: ABC and SBS stations are all able to be received in Gladstone.

column1: The Central Queensland editions of WIN News and Seven Local News
column2: both regularly feature news content directly relating to the Gladstone region. Seven Queensland employ a journalist and camera operator in Gladstone
column3: while WIN Television dispatch a news crew from Rockhampton to cover news stories in Gladstone.

column1: The weekly 'What's On' segment on Seven Local News is also presented from Gladstone.
